item.title: The Princess Bride, 1987
item.description:
tl;dr didn't enjoy it that much (very funny at times), but it's great family movie.


Story is framed in weird way. Plot of Princess Bride is grandpa telling his sick grandson a fairy tale. For that reason, we are to take plot as exactly that, a fairy tale. Yet, plot is very self-aware about being formulaic, as grandson can't stop (correctly) predicting whichever happens - grandpa has no chance of creating suspense.

Thus, Princess Bride exists in a curious superposition between spoof and sincere. What bothered me is that it wasn't good enough in being either of those two.

If it were sincere, Princess Bride just isn't interesting enough. Action and setpieces were dull and visuals are not fulfilling of the "fairy tale" promise. Notice here that Princess Bride cost $40mil(!!). It doesn't have reason to feel like a low-budget spoof.

And yet, it isn't spoofy enough. I didn't have enough of occasional smart jokes, low-budget feel, self-awareness, bad action and insistent clichés. Is everyone ultra honorable (or ultra evil) because it's a fairy tale or because it's making fun of fairy tales? Phrase "true love" is uttered so many times it lost all meaning. At one point I got so lulled in that I was genuinely shocked at Inigo getting mortally wounded - too bad, security is returned by him being a-ok in next scene.

Is Princess Bride mocking anyone demanding more complex stories? Maybe acts as finger to all the deconstructions and ironic detachments to the genre, and shows genuine love for fairy tales as something comfy for everyone who was a kid at one point? Is presented predictability of fairy tales exact reason for their comfyness?

After writing all this out, I would just say it's good family movie, and my qualms don't apply for that purpose. Kids can enjoy it, and humor is mature enough for adults too.

item.title: Vertigo, 1958
item.description:
tl;dr doesn't hold up

yeaah I don't think this should be revered nowhere near as-is. Crazy how impenetrably positive discourse about Vertigo really is.

Spoilers ahead.

For the most part I thought Vertigo tried to condemn Scottie's behaviour - he acts as a saviour merely to exploit mentally unstable woman, and later moulds another woman to his fetish. Okay, Vertigo, I'm listening... Nah, any crumb of psychological analysis or depth is thrown right out the window when it turns out Judy likes, and is even obsessed with Scottie's rapeyness. Scottie is downright rewarded for his behaviour. To make matters worse, Scottie-Judy relationship is damn shit. They at least have to have SOME chemistry to justify their batshit pathological infatuations with each other, right? AND THEY ONLY KNOW EACH OTHER FOR, LIKE, 3 DAYS! Maybe erotic toxic-hot-relationship trope is attempted here? I would rather go with "Hitchcock is a perv". Uninspired, idiotic dynamic of the two leads is the hill where Vertigo irreparibly dies.

Moving the bad out of the way, I think Vertigo has great potential. Central idea is very fun - you have these two people, both pretending to be someone they are not. They get in mad love, but they fall for manufactured personas. Tragic happens, plot twist outta nowhere, masks fall, everything is revealed. Both left with nothing but guilt from role they played. And they meet again. This time, no acting. Can they forgive deception? Will they even like each other? How much pretending is "ok" in romance? Is all romance pretending? Will they ever live up to their act? Can they be together if they are connected by guilt? These are all absolutely phenomenal themes for a romance-crime drama. Add in moral ambiguity from crime, and Vertigo suddenly sounds great, maybe even like some edgier Before!

Finally, Vertigo really doesn't hold up. By modern standards it can't be a thriller, right? First half is dull, second one is too slow yet concludes too hastily. Plot twist seems like a joke, it's briefly revealed in middle of a random scene. Almost as if they were shy of showing little pwoty-twisty. Soundtrack is obnoxious and is too hyped up even when scene is boring. Ending is fucking laugh-out-loud funny and feels straight out of absurdist comedy skit. Hitchcock certainly doesn't seem like master of suspense here.
It's really not about "respect for the OGs". Psycho feels revolutional - deceptively smart portrayal of villain, decoy protagonist, complete plot shift and nudity. Psycho doesn't hold up now too, but it is clear how DARING it is for its era.
Vertigo doesn't have that kind of smarts going for it. Skip this one.

item.title: Cowboy Bebop, 1998
item.description:
I was honestly blindsided by Cowboy Bebop. Very confused with "one of all time greats" in terms of anime glory, I couldn't help myself but think Cowboy Bebop is most overrated piece of media I have ever laid my eyes upon. Music and artstyle slap very hard while atmosphere and voice acting are great, yes, but that's about it. I hated the characters and their plain coolness serving only to hide their shallowness. I hated how no plot has any context to it, how cheap and anticlimactical everything is. How most episodes are results of completely crazy contrivances happening in-universe and as such seem random or dumb. How action is barren of consequences and critically lacks weight - Spike dodges bullets and death with such ease that I brushed off any setpiece as boring, safe and ultimately - meaningless.

Around the episode 13 (exact half) it hit me like a truck.

All of this is completely intentional. No, please hear me out. Beware light spoilers ahead, although I don't think they would ruin your experience.

Cowboy Bebop is esentially meditation on nihilism. Or at least some sick apathy.

Action in Cowboy Bebop consists of violence and destruction with smooth jazz playing over. Something akin to Akira, but without youthful rage and angst or technological paranoia - just pure chaos. Death is cheap, violence is mundane or maybe even soothing. Nobody is surprised of all the carnage, crime runs rampant and there is TV show for bounty hunting. Political unrest and poverty, human experimentation, colonialization and secret police are all glossed over because really, really nobody cares. Gang lives in literal, emotional and societal vacuum. Even crew's dog (symbol of loyalty) is just a "data dog", pointing out transactional type of relationships in this universe.

Money is treated with irony. Even as a master thief, Faye is extremely clumsy with money. Most of the bounties can't be collected because of random formality or some other contrivance. Gang never profits, even to the point of often being hungry. And yet, money is only motivator for everything.

Main characters act with utmost apathy. Faye robs the gang regularly, but nothing comes out of it. Gang has few infights, deadly weapons used with no remorse, and at the end of the episode everyone is back together. They all gravitate towards the Bebop, but not because they have anything in it, just out of sheer inertia. Spike's whole personality can be summarized with apathy, as he does only what he pleases, only when he pleases, commonly making him out to be a douche.

Character backstories aren't there to provide motivation, but to strip characters away from any notion of meaning. Faye is a no one, as everybody who was connected to her previous life died (again, in violent chaos) while her misfortune was clearly pupeteered. Faye literally got her personality and purpose taken away. Of course, she wields extremely sexualized action-girl persona to make up for it. A facade of coolness; completely empty inside. Very similar approach with Spike, whose backstory is presetned in a manner I found especially poignant. On death bed, before his eyes appears just a glimmer of purpose once had - unclear, surreal recollection of previous life. But some malignant force doesn't let him move on, and he is forced to defy death again and again. Dreams of past recur as a cruel reminder that he had something to fight for once.

Cowboy Bebop is melancholy incarnate. Eclectical approach makes it seem like series itself has troubled identity stuck between past and future - mixing obvious western, retro-futurism, scifi and jazz influences. But in the end everything works out exceptionally well. Even the supposed superficiality makes sense retrospectively: everyone laments the past because all the purposeful moments happened way back - only thing left is to reminisce.

item.title: Sympathy for Mr. Vengeance, 2002 (contains spoilers)
item.description:
This review may contain spoilers.

Definitely Park Chan-Wook's most stylistically distinct movie, which makes it very fun watch even as it is probably his slowest. Ryu (Shin Ha-Kyun) being deaf almost makes Sympathy for Mr. Vengeance have a Lynchian atmosphere, amplified by primal rage that pulses through, but is always suffocated and never satisfied. I must say that Sympathy breaks this rule just once, when we get irregularly gratifying revenge against organ harvesters, even though its downplayed as unfulfilling. Sound design is pure bliss, absence of music and focus on unnerving weeps, industrial tools, violence or otherwise complete silence combines into powerful feeling that characters in Sympathy just want to scream at the unjust universe, but nobody is there to hear them. Long uninterrupted, voyeuristic shots lacking music evoke Tsai Ming-Liang as well as Cure.

On the other hand, I found Sympathy for Mr. Vengeance to have somewhat unjustified violence and disturbing content. Ryu's sister' suicide didn't feel organic, neither did little girl's death which was even very predictable. They pretty much both serve as plot devices. Torture of Ryu's girlfriend seemed unneeded too, and maybe too harsh for attempt at empathethic portrayal of revenge. I promised I won't compare it to Oldboy, but Oldboy has more fantastical premise and characters yet Oldboy seems organic, and I sympathized with both protagonist and antagonist more. Don't get me wrong, I liked the characters (phenomenal acting btw), but story was a bit too much for me. I dare even say for the first time I feel Song Kang-Ho got little outacted. Only moment of extreme violence that was justified imo is the last scene. With its acutely diabolus ex machina ending, it is the grief and remorse that brutalizes Mr. Park's heart, a great subversion of the already worn out neverending-cycle-of-violence trope.

Enjoyed it thoroughly myself in spite of some pet peeves - for Chan-Wook and grim Korea cinema fans must watch, for others I don't think so.

item.title: Black Mirror: Crocodile, 2017 (contains spoilers)
item.description:
This review may contain spoilers.

i wanted to review episodes after i finish them all, but i'm very...passionate about this episode so here goes the review.

I thought Nosedive was the worst episode because it felt like a cheap BM copy. I then thought Playtest was the worst episode because of same reason - fundamental misunderstanding of what made BM good. To be precise, most of the Season 3+ episodes make same mistakes imo.

Crocodile definitely takes the cake; slaughters it with hammer, cement block, strangles it and throws it into lake.

Why does this episode remind us of so many earlier ones? Remember when Black Mirror was good? Remember this song from 15 million merits, the Hot Shots, the Wraith Babes? Remember Entire History of You, but boring this time?

Black Mirror is NOT about having tech devices as a plot drive. Metalhead did it, but Metalhead admits to being a scifi thriller and nothing else. Crocodile has no excuses. Crocodile does nothing with tech, tech is just way for main character to be hunted. Tech is even a good guy in this episode - authorities can finally better catch criminals! For example there is zero talk about privacy; software that can scan anyone's face and find them on internet is another plot device (in last episode too, lazy). What I'm saying - no social commentary. Does it "require" social commentary? No, of course. But what does Crocodile have exactly? It doesn't have good "detective" story I can tell you that. Main character is found by extremely convoluted set of events. Crocodile is an awful drama story as well. Needlessly fucked up, irrational and...not interesting at all. Not a thriller, not a love story, shitty scifi nevertheless. So, why does Crocodile exist? I honestly thought the subjectivness of memories was gonna be a point of this episode as a foil to Entire History of You pure memories-as-reality, but Crocodile comes with no thoughts included.

Maybe most importantly, WHY DOES IT FORCE THE FUCKED UP ENDING OH GOD. I literally laughed out loud when Mia saw the baby. And then kept facepalming myself when they revealed the baby was blind. Guess the writer felt all warm inside. Black Mirror doesn't HAVE to be bad endings with a cruel twist. But no, lets wallow in sadism and context-barren twists. That's what BM is, right? Having sadistic twists. And the hamster thing is honestly dumb as fuck. I guess Mia couldn't be left off the hook. Lazy writing, again.

Above all, Crocodile was PURE boring and anticlimactic (no, baby killing isn't climactic). Honest to god I can't find single redeeming thing about Crocodile.

item.title: Paris, Je T'Aime, 2006
item.description:
pretty uninspired all round. Kinda felt like a set of commercials for Paris more than work anyone wanted to make. In spite of that, Coens were pretty funny and were most out of place (in a good way), Payne was very good, Tykwer montage honestly great. And yeah I'm (un)fairly biased toward Doyle whatever he films.

i honestly don't like this format, it's very hard to actually create dramatic, meaningful stories about random moments in life of people we know nothing about. I don't think it's completely unfruitful though - Payne and Tykwer segments obviously worked by getting into little, dense character studies from the first frame. Same reason why i didnt like Schmitz segment - for it to be dramatic in such short story it had too much "kick the dog" effect, resulting in just quick, but shallow sadness hormone injection.

Some I felt were especially dumb was Quaise de Seine (about muslim girl), which had Dora the Explorer level insight in minorities, with exchange as stupid as "why do you wear hijab you're beautiful";"i actually WANT to wear hijab, it's my freedom", as if viewers are not aware of any other cultures existing.
And the first one I viscerally hated for reasons I can't really pinpoint.

If you want to watch sweeter, more connected stories taking place in one city, go watch Love Actually. It actually had some kind of payoff.

item.title: Black Mirror episodes ranked by "we live in a Society" factor
item.description:
"We live in a Society" factor is based on how (un)subtle the episode is, how much it mocks fucking normies (ree) and how likely it is to be liked by your futurphobic boomer parents. Also see: father I cannot click a book.

Check the notes for justifications.

Upon making the list I see that first 11 episodes (on list) have straight up point about Society, while others are dramas/thrillers exploring average individuals in near future. Crocodile and USS Callister feel like neither, and Playtest and Metalhead exists in their own worlds.
In my humble opinion entries 1-7 are in Society too much while other (8-11) are fine.

I didn't include the movie because I got the worst ending and never cared for more because it sucks ass.

NOTE: This doesn't reflect my general ranking of episodes. Just the Society part.

  1. Black Mirror: Nosedive

    I don't think this needs any explanation. Subtlety found horrifically butchered. Nosedive prime suspect.

  2. Black Mirror: Fifteen Million Merits

    Here's the thing with these kind of episodes taking place in a brutally on-the-nose allegories for late stage capitalism - they take themselves too seriously to the point of parody.
    Same thing with Nosedive, people are acting just too damn idiotic for this to be intelligent critique. And 15 million merits doesn't shy from laughing at its supposed audience - in this episode people are rude imbeciles only watching sub-60 iq shows and slaving away their lives.

  3. Black Mirror: White Bear

    Although I think lesson of this episode is extremely important, I'm not very happy with execution.

    People are shown as mindless sadists, and White Bear packs a lot more of "fate worse than death" than needed. Unnecessary 20 minute reiteration of its themes also makes me think White Bear is not very confident in its audience and/or Society.

  4. Black Mirror: Shut Up and Dance

    Plot of the episode itself I really like for reasons identical to National Anthem. Grounded in reality, having completely beliavable character motivations and reactions, Shut Up and Dance expresses genuine fear of present state of privacy with a fine thriller/drama.

    BUT...and this is a big "BUT..." ending cements it as one of the higher entries on this list.
    Firstly, unbeliavably dumb plot twist at the end that serves no purpose to theme of the episode (even is detrimental to it) and THEN somehow even dumber attempt at using "le meme culture" - probably just to drive home the point that writers are completely out of touch with contemporary/internet culture.

    It could've been a commentary on digital blackmailing and security, it could've been meditation on "for the lulz" philosophy, it could've been analysis of internet vigilantism, but ending cements it as none of the above whilst trying ALL of the above. Shut Up and Dance is thus made completely obsolete by National Anthem and White Bear.

  5. Black Mirror: Men Against Fire

    Ditto White Bear. Extremely important theme, but with 20 minute soliloquy explaining that idea because Black Mirror apparently thinks we are dumb. And again with "fate worse than death" scenario. Ol' reliable I guess.

  6. Black Mirror: Black Museum

    Ditto White Christmas. Just remove insightful commentary, add creepy-pasta level cruelty, shamelessly copy the structure and reference all older episodes.

    Clone of a clone of a clone of White Christmas.

  7. Black Mirror: Hated in the Nation

    Again, internet vigilantism.
    We live in a Society where people c̶a̶n̶c̶e̶l̶ kill other people.

  8. Black Mirror: The Waldo Moment

    I have no idea why is this episode hated so much. I can't even say it's "we live in a Society" as Waldo phenomenon unambigously happened in my country! And it portrays people somewhat sympathetically, they are just sick of being lied to.

  9. Black Mirror: Hang the DJ

    Very on-the-nose for dehumanizing instant relationships that hookup apps give. Good ending of Hang the DJ averts the "we live in a Society", as themes of the episode aren't insisting on everything being shit, but on contrary that technology can't kill true love. It feels maybe too honest for Black Mirror lol.

  10. Black Mirror: White Christmas

    Very similar feeling with White Bear, although admitedly this is a much better episode. I feel themes of this episode are important (commodity of being distanced from suffering that first world commodities cause, government power granted by contemporary technology etc) but it's a tad too "evil" for me to like.

    Psychological torture of first cookie and making culprit suffer for 100 years just so were juuust over the edge for me in terms of cruelty.
    Too bad White Christmas was only beggining. Last great episode imo.

...plus 9 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
